subject: CBS Evening News with Katie Couric E-Mail Alert
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Good afternoon. This is Russ Mitchell filling in for
  Katie.
 
We’ll begin our coverage tonight with the
  riveting testimony from one of the accused Duke lacrosse players – and
  from the man accused of unethical conduct in the case, Durham district attorney Mike Nifong. Last
  year Nifong called the accused students a “bunch of hooligans,”
  but admitted in court today that he “maybe got carried away.” If
  convicted by the state bar’s disciplinary board, Nifong could be stripped
  of his law license. Byron Pitts will have the story.
 
The computer breakdown aboard the international
  space station is keeping the astronauts busy and NASA consumed with
  recovering critical Russian computer systems. But what’s the source of
  the problem? Some are pointing to the station’s new solar panels;
  others blame a connector that was plugged in when Atlantis docked. Daniel
  Sieberg will have the latest.
 
In the Middle East, on Hamas’ first full day
  in control of Gaza,
  triumphant mobs looted Fatah offices and areas and tore into the office of
  Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas. Richard Roth will have the latest from Israel.
 
Next, we’ll tell you about some disturbing
  numbers brought to light by the Pentagon’s latest mental health study.
  Thirty-one percent of Marines, 38 percent of soldiers and 49 percent of
  national guardsmen returning from Iraq
  and Afghanistan
  reported psychological symptoms – from depression to alcohol abuse.
  David Martin will look at whether the care they receive at home is adequate.
 
We’re keeping tabs on the housing crunch in
  the United States,
  and as Anthony Mason will report tonight, mortgage rates – and delinquencies
  on those mortgages – are on the rise.
 
And for our Assignment America this week, Steve
  Hartman will introduce you to a young lady who’s been acting more like
  a fairy godmother. She has a potentially fatal disease, but that isn’t
  stopping her from using her talents to help others.
 
Thanks and I hope you have a wonderful weekend,
 




Russ Mitchell
CouricandCo@cbs.com
